issues.title: SegmentTimeline in MPD not in par with sidx boxes
issues.body:
When I dash an mp4(h264/aac 48k) with MP4Box, with RAP/keyframes every 10 seconds, I have the proper timing in the generated mp4, but the segments in SegmentTimeline differs.

(I'm going to limit to the first 3 segments, as the issue is the same for the whole file)

The first three sidx boxes have earliest presentation times of (timescale 12288) respectively:
0, 122880, 245760 which are exactly 0, 10 and 20 seconds.

The tfdt boxes have the following track offsets:
video (timescale 12288): 0, 122880, 245760
audio (timescale 48000): 0, 484352, 964608 (which are aligned to aac encoding window of 1024 samples)

The SegmentTimeline starts with:

``` xml
<SegmentList timescale="1000">
 <SegmentTimeline>
     <S t="0" d="10090"/>
     <S d="10005" r="1"/>
     <S d="10000"/>
```

I understand that the audio being longer creates this issue (484352/48000 = 1009.06~). What I do not understand is why my segments are not interlapping in the timeline. I expect something like:

``` xml
<SegmentList timescale="1000">
 <SegmentTimeline>
     <S t="0" d="10090"/>
     <S t="10000" d="10005"/>
     <S t="20000" d="10005"/>
     <S t="30000" d="10000"/>
```

Because to play the time (in ts 1000) 10045 for example, I will need segment 1 for audio, but segment 2 for video.

_Thinking out loud_:
It's not going to cause issue with short videos as even if the user seeks at 10045, segment 2 will start playing, and nobody is going to notice the 45ms of missing sound, but this can cause minor issue with long video, if I have a 2hours video (720 segments) and the user seeks near the end, at 1h40, I'll have 3 seconds of sync error.

issues.title: Request: MP4Client to output to stdout
issues.body:
This is a feature request rather than a bug, but it would be very useful if MP4Client could output the data to stdout rather than direct to the audio/visual hardware.

While I'm sure many developers/users would find this useful for chaining the output to other commands, my specific use would be to allow playback of MPEG-DASH streams within the squeezebox music system. There is a plugin which will play simple DASH streams created by MP4Box using vlc to handle the transcoding (see https://github.com/Mac0z/playDASH) but this cannot handle more complex streams such as the BBC's test MPEG-DASH feed (http://rdmedia.bbc.co.uk/dash/ondemand/bbb/2/client_manifest-audio.mpd) which MP4Client handles perfectly.

issue_comments.body: Thanks for the update, I appreciate it's not simple

issues.title: [DASH] Add missing DASH-IF IOP profiles.
issues.body:
Hi!

While creating DASH HEVC media according to DASH-IF IOP guidelines (I'm using the publicly available version v2.9, which is a draft of soon to be released v3.0 (http://dashif.org/w/2014/08/DASH-IF-IOP-v2.90.pdf), I noticed that MP4Box knows only about DASH and DASH-264/AVC profiles (at least that's what I see in `mp4box -h dash` (`-profile` option)). Since HEVC is now also the part of DASH-IF IOP, it would be nice to have additional profiles for it. Perhaps, something similar to DASH-264/AVC, for example: "dashevc265:onDemand" and "dashevc265:live".

pull_requests.title: Added missing DASH-IF IOP profiles.
pull_requests.body:
This change resolves the issue #41. It adds missing DASH-IF IOP profiles, as well as obsoletes the current, wrong ones. Using obsolete profiles will produce a warning.

The logic of using DASH-IF IOP profiles was also changed. Previously, using `dashavc264:live` was implicitly enabling `-url-template`, for example. But since `:live` and `:onDemand` parts are not included in the names of profiles anymore, users have to be more specific about what they want. For, example, in order to achieve the same behavior as in the previous example, the user must specify: `-profile "dashif264" -url-template`. For on-demand case, it will be something like this: `-profile "dashif264" -single-segment`.

This change is only about correct identifiers for different DASH-IF IOP profiles. Strictly speaking, each profile has its own restrictions, so, ideally, MP4Box would generate some warnings or errors if the user wants to do something that is restricted. I'm not sure that it's needed, though. First of all, it would complicate MP4Box, which is bad. And another reason is that perhaps it's a job of validators to check for compliance.

Anyway, with this change, it's now possible to conform to different DASH-IF IOP profiles, using not only H.264/AVC, but H.265/HEVC as well.

issue_comments.body:
@jeanlf, thanks for fixing it!

But I have some additional questions. -bs-switching by default is set to "inband". So, when I use multiple video streams that use the same codec, in MPD I see "avc1.*" values in Representation@codecs. But when I use multiple video streams that use different codecs, in MPD I see "avc3.*" values Representation@codecs. dash.js (1.2.0, and the latest from the development branch) in this case doesn't show the video (black screen), although the playback works and I hear the audio. I've tried to set -bs-switching to "merge". MP4Box reported "[DASH]: Could not merge AVC|H264 SPS from different files (same SPS ID used) - disabling bitstream switching", and in MPD, values in Representation@codecs are again set to "avc1.*", although the bitstream switching is turned off (this attribute is missing and by default it's set to "false", according to the DASH specification). But at the same time, this version works fine in dash.js. Well, actually, DASH-IF IOP v2.0 says in 4.2.2 (line 20): "Clients are expected to support Inband Storage for SPS/PPS based ISO/IEC 14496-15, 20 Amendment 2 [22], i.e. sample entry 'avc3' and 'avc4'". So, I assume that this is a bug in dash.js. But before reporting it, I'd like to better understand this topic.

So, my questions are:
1. These avc modes (avc1, avc3, etc.). I don't know anything about them, and a quick search on this topic didn't give me any results. Could you recommend me some source of information where these modes are described? Or, perhaps, maybe you could explain it yourself? I'm not looking for low-level details. I just want to know enough in order to produce correct media.
2. Since SPSs can't be merged, does it mean that it's better to avoid media that uses different codecs for different video Representations in the case when bitstream switching is needed? If so, then what are the problems (assuming that they exist) (including potential ones) for a media player to switch between such Representations?

@jeanlf, thanks for clarification! My mistake was that I was thinking about the @bitstreamSwitching in MPD as about an indication that a media player must (or must not) attempt to switch between Representations.

@jeanlf, I have more questions related to this topic.

Right now I'm using GPAC 0.5.2-DEV-rev80-g29b60b6-master. I have a video that consists of these Representations:
- 360p; Profile: Constrained Baseline; Level: 3.0; Codec: 42c01e
- 720p; Profile: High; Level 3.1; Codec: 64001f
- 1080p; Profile: High: Level 4.0; Codec: 640028

Questions:
1. When I'm creating a DASH media by using the "dashavc264:**live**" profile, I see that the `bitstreamSwitching="true"`, which is expected, since the default mode is "inband". I also see that the "avc3" mode is used. But what's strange is that all 3 Representations have `codecs="avc3.42c01e"`. I was expecting that the codec part for each Representation must be unique. Is everything correct here?
2. When I'm creating a DASH media by using the "dashavc264:**onDemand**" profile, I see that the `bitstreamSwitching` attribute is missing, and the "avc1" mode is used. I didn't expect this, so I specified `-bs-switching inband`, and I got the same result - nothing has changed. Looks like something is wrong here, but there are not warnings or errors.
@jeanlf, I tried in GPAC version 0.5.2-DEV-rev87-ga51f89f-master, but this attribute is still missing. I used these files: http://1drv.ms/1zaXrZZ

@jeanlf, I'm not sure what you were trying to say, but here's what I get:

``` xml
<MPD xmlns="urn:mpeg:dash:schema:mpd:2011" minBufferTime="PT1.500000S" type="static" mediaPresentationDuration="PT0H0M52.21S" profiles="urn:mpeg:dash:profile:isoff-live:2011, http://dashif.org/guildelines/dash264">
```

So, as you can see, the MPD element doesn't have the "maxSegmentDuration" attribute.

The command I was using is:

```
mp4box.exe -dash 4000 -frag 4000 -rap -frag-rap -profile "dashavc264:live" -segment-name %s- "360p-700k-baseline30.mp4" "720p-1300k-high31.mp4" "1080p-2600k-high40.mp4" "audio-256k.m4a" -out "sintel.mpd"
```

@jeanlf, I checked the version by using `mp4box.exe -version`, and got "GPAC version 0.5.2-DEV-rev87-ga51f89f-master". I installed it by using the "gpac-0.5.2-DEV-rev87-ga51f89f-master-x64.exe". That's the latest one on the web-site: http://gpac.wp.mines-telecom.fr/downloads/gpac-nightly-builds/.

Also, I don't see MPD elements in your comments. I see the XML declaration, and then 3 dots "...". Here's the screenshot: http://1drv.ms/1AUILSJ. Maybe GitHub escapes it :). Could you put it in the code block? (https://guides.github.com/features/mastering-markdown/)
@jeanlf, got it working in GPAC version 0.5.2-DEV-rev96-gfc92dbc-master. Thanks!

commit_comments.body: Typo: adAptation.

Not sure whether it was intentional, but as far as I understand, now there's no correct defaults, and people will need to always specify the CP mode, which is not very convenient. Ideally, it should be like you select the profile, and correct defaults are being used.

Yes, correct. I forgot about the default enum value. But it seems that now this default is applied to all profiles. For the standard DASH profiles, previously CP was in REP. Not sure that changing such behavior is a good thing. Someone already may depend on it.

These "old" profiles that MP4Box was using are now covered by the new "dashif264". You may also notice that it was still possible to use old ones, in order to not break anyone who updated MP4Box.

I see no reason to advertise in the help old profiles. This may be misleading.

And speaking of "supersseeded" - no, nothing is superseeded. Profiles from v2 are still valid, and they're not deprecated by v3.

"DASH-IF AVC/264" is the old name of DASH-IF IOP. I'd recommend to use the new name, since this doesn't require to know history.

And they're not deprecated or obsolete DASH-IF IOP profiles. They are still active and valid. It's just those enums that MP4Box was using are wrong. They don't map to any profile that is defined by DASH-IF IOP. Well, they sort of functionally equal to "DASH-AVC/264", but these ":live" and ":onDemand" are something abstract and not existing.

I see no reason to rename old enums. However you'll call them, you won't be able to map it to any profile defined in DASH-IF IOP, because the way how it was previously implemented is wrong. So, I'd stay with old names, since they're less misleading. I'd stay away from specifying the IOP version, since this is meaningless. In fact, why v2, if the same profile is defined in v1 as well? So, yes, old names are wrong, but better.

These are not v2 profiles. These are not even IOP profiles :)

I was also not precise. These are not obsolete DASH-IF IOP profiles. These are unique to MP4Box things that sort of remind one of the IOP's profiles. And because proper profiles were introduced, these enums were marked as obsolete.
"dashif264", "SD" and "HD" are 3 different, valid and active IOP profiles. They're defined in v2. I'd like them to be added back.

issues.title: Representation segment index doesn't start with a segment index box which indexes the index segment
issues.body:
Sorry about the long title.

In 6.4.6.3 Representation Index Segment:

> The Segment Index for each Media Segments is concatenated in order, preceded by a single
> Segment Index box that indexes the Index Segment. This initial Segment Index box shall have one
> entry in its loop for each Media Segment, and each entry refers to the Segment Index information for
> a single Media Segment.

When I use MP4Box to create a DASH stream from MPEG-TS files, the representation index doesn't start with this initial segment index box, but instead just has the segment indexes for media segments.

issue_comments.body:
Essentially, a valid segment index file starts with:

styp ; sidx (all reference_types = 1) ; sidx (all reference_types = 0) ; sidx (all reference_types = 0) ; etc.

Most likely this requires changes in `src/media_tools/dash_segmenter.c`. See `m2ts_sidx_flush_entry` and `dasher_mp2t_segment_file` in particular. It's not clear to me how to hold off on writing the indexes until we have all of them so we can write the master index first.

Looking at a representation index I have, it looks like it only has one 'sidx'. The spec says:

> The Segment Index for each Media Segments is concatenated in order, preceded by a single
> Segment Index box that indexes the Index Segment. This initial Segment Index box shall have one
> entry in its loop for each Media Segment, and each entry refers to the Segment Index information for
> a single Media Segment.

This is confusingly written, but since the master 'sidx' has one entry per segment, and each entry points to "the" index for a segment, that seems to imply that each media segment has exactly one 'sidx', and segments can't share an 'sidx'.

I'll bring this up at the next MPEG meeting and make sure that this is the intent, and if so, as if it can be made more explicit.
The`<SegmentBase>` was also missing @presentationTimeOffset
You're right, thanks for pointing me to this.

issue_comments.body:
1) what do you mean by "change some chunks (frame data only)" ? If you change frame data, you need re-encoding of the whole chunk. This may have impact on codec compatibility of the new encdoded data and the existing file , you need to mke sure the same codecs settings are used...

2) using simple cat may only be possible if the modified chunk has exactly the same duration as the source one. One way to do so is :+1: 
- to prepare the video as a set of  fragmented files (say 1 sec), using for example  "-dash" option of MP4Box in "live" profile
- whenever you have to edit one fragmented file, concat the init segment and the file (simple cat) and  edit (if needed, unfrag the file using -inter 500). To refragment the result, use -dash option on the modified video, with the -tfdt N where N was the tfdt time of the edited segment (you can use -diso frag.m4s to find the tfdt).
- when you have to distribute the result, concat (simple cat) the init segments and all the fragmented files.

The merging of SPS only happens when using -bs-switching merge option, it's a special mode where SPSs from the different inputs are combined, when possible, in a single track description to allow for bitstream switching in 'avc1' mode rather than 'avc3' mode

Indeed the isLeading flag was droped during import, now fixed in rev 5587. thanks for the report

1) (and same applies to HEVC): AVC and HEVC store codec config in SPS and PPS (and VPS for HEVC). The "codec parameters" can be stored in the sample entry of the track (eg in avc1 or hvc1), in which case they shall not occur in the sample data. Or they can be stored in the sample data (avc3 and hev1) in which case they may not be present in the sample entry; this mode allows for dynamic change of the codec config but complexifies a bit the seeking (need to find the closest previous IDR with the right parameter sets). 

2) no, because most (if not all) players are capable of handling non "bitstream-switching" sequences. The terminology here is a bit confusing: the fact that you don't have bitstreamSwitching="true" for an adaptationSet does not mean the client cannot switch between the representations of that set, it means that the client will have to re-parse a moov (init segment) before the switch.

There is now such a feature in rev 5601. In your case :
-dump-udta PANA file.mp4 -out test.udta: will dump root udta(s) of type PANA as a set of boxes
-udta 0:box=test.udta file.mp4: will import root udta from test.udta

There are actually two possibilities:
- either using a representation index which is a master sidx with sub sidx for each segment; in this case, only one index is used for the whole representation
- or using a separate index which is a regular sidx, potentially chained

In any case we do it wrong :) I have for the time being commented the generation of the sidx file, since it is optional, so that we don't generate non-conformant sequences. 
As you noticed, patching the code will require a bit of time since this code was not originally designed to produce indexes as decided in the DASH standard.

--static-mp4box will not use all modules, but the configure does not change (hence the display of the detected config). 

are you sure a clean VM is used with each env ? we had bugs on travisCI before the make clean was introduced (https://travis-ci.org/gpac/gpac/builds/50523813) 
anyway it doesn't hurt to add this

1) this is strange, you should have different codecs params for each representation, could you share your test files somewhere ?

2) check the spec, this is normal: onDemand forces that each representation consists of a single segment self-intialiizing (eg with moov included). Bitstream switching is therefore ignored

We're thinking about that but it's a bit more complex than a straight stdout redirection:
- audio and video may need to be sent on different pipes
- reconfiguration may happen (audio sample rate change, video resolution change), which will need to be signalled in some way

Handling this in compressed domain is not always possible, since the way DASH switching works may not always allow for direct concatenation of files (multiple moov boxes -> invalid content). This would require a complete remuxing of the source which we don't support yet.

we'll keep you posted whenever we progress on that topic...

Here's what I found out: the lower bitrate (gear1) uses PID 257 for audio and PID 258 for video. Other bitrates use PID257 for video and 258 for audio. And the PMT section_number is always the same (meaning no change in stream config). So after playing back the low bitrate and switching up, the video decoder is fed AAC access units and the audio decoder is fed H264 ones !!

Not sure what we can do about this, but you can instruct the client to use maxQuality by default (config file, DASH section, StartRepresentation=maxBandwidth). And maybe file a bug to Apple ;)

called :  https://github.com/gpac/gpac/blob/master/src/utils/os_config_init.c#L740
defined : https://github.com/gpac/gpac/blob/master/src/utils/os_config_init.c#L221 
and libgpac create the default config https://github.com/gpac/gpac/blob/master/src/utils/os_config_init.c#L748 
so the .bt GUI exists in the GPAC cfg and we can display the GUI. After this commit the libgpac considers that the GPAC.cfg already exists and the default config will never created, because will passed always from here https://github.com/gpac/gpac/blob/master/src/utils/os_config_init.c#L724

pull_requests.title: Help for Sandbox
pull_requests.body:
Bonjour Jean,

Voici les quelques modifications que j'ai retrouvé de mes commits sur notre SVN, il y a de cela plus de 8 mois maintenant. Peu de choses à changer au niveau du code finalement, si ce n'est l'importance de mettre le fichier config in-app et (j'ai supposé à l'époque) d'avoir un référent in-app pour aller chercher le gui.bt. De notre côté nous allions chercher une vidéo à lire de la même manière, vidéo stockée à l'intérieur de l'application. Je n'ai pas pu compiler ou tester le code n'ayant pas de Mac sous la main. Ce ne sont là que des propositions à tester.

A noter également qu'il faille retirer le fameux appel de task_for_pid() qui est interdit par le service d'Apple. Nous ne sommes pas allé plus loin dans la soumission donc il est possible que d'autres éléments bloquent le processus de soumission.

Pour ce qui est de la Sandbox, il s'agit en fait d'un système de sécurité mis en place par Apple pour contrôler les actions des applications. Cette Sandbox est obligatoire pour toute soumission à l'App Store.  Concrètement, la Sandbox est une "safe zone" dans laquelle va évoluer l'application. Un dossier "caché" est créé sur la machine et tout s'opère à l'intérieur de celui-ci. Par défaut, tout accès extérieur est interdit que ce soit en lecture ou en écriture. 

La Sandbox est régie par des règles définies par un fichier appelé appName.entitlements (donc ici mp4client.entitlements) à placer obligatoirement dans mp4client.app/Contents/Resources/. Ce fichier contient au minimum une instruction qui active la Sandbox, puis chaque instruction correspondant à des actions susceptibles d'être utilisées par l'application parmi une liste définie dans la doc d'apple : https://developer.apple.com/library/ios/documentation/Miscellaneous/Reference/EntitlementKeyReference/Chapters/AboutEntitlements.html

Voici le fichier entitlements que j'ai rédigé pour le player : 

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<!DOCTYPE plist PUBLIC "-//Apple//DTD PLIST 1.0//EN" "http://www.apple.com/DTDs/PropertyList-1.0.dtd">
<plist version="1.0">
<dict>

@cconcolato I agree that TRUN values are optional, if soTFHD default values must be used. In that case, when TTML packed with profile Live or onDemand, TFHD size and duration defaults are 0 and TRUN is empty so there is no way for the player to know the sample size and sample duration

With profile "dashavc264:live", "dashavc264:onDemand", TFHD are correctly filled.

![trun](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11294830/6593285/9513f270-c7d7-11e4-8795-7427c1cd195b.png)
![tfhd](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11294830/6593288/97700716-c7d7-11e4-95a6-fa01f49dacec.png)

For TTML begin and end values : Here is what you can find in  "Information technology — Coding of audio-visual objects — Part 30: Timed text and other visual overlays in ISO base media file format":
"The duration of the TTML document carried in a sample may be less than the sample duration, but should not be greater." It means that is it recommended to clamp end and begin value between  the sample timestamp and sample timestamp+duration

Now, as  nigelmegitt said, it is "should" and "not shall". So, it is up to you.

For the 'trun'/'tfhd' issue, :
-> the construction is legal but values are wrong ( ttml sample size is not 0 and sample duration is not 0)
-> for sidx box, it was my first implementation, but  i saw streams with multple TTML sample by moof (one subtitle per sample, it is stupid but it looks legal)
For me it is ok.

@rbouqueau I don't agree that the duration constraint requires the DASHer to modify the begin/end values. The sample period defines the active period for any individual TTML document and the implementation can temporally clip the content at runtime. There's no need to modify the TTML document content in this way. 

In fact, because it's a _should_ not a _shall_ as referenced above, that means that implementations must have a way to deal with content that isn't clipped/clamped (whatever term you prefer) anyhow.

@rbouqueau I'm not sure what mechanism you're using to mark samples as redundant - it's not an approach described in EBU Tech3381 for example. Regardless, there's a general case that is not be covered by that approach, when the sample boundaries and the subtitle times aren't aligned, e.g. because you want a fixed sample duration: Sample n, time 00:00:10 -> 00:00:15: ``` ...

Subtitle 1

... ``` Sample n+1, time 00:00:15 -> 00:00:20: ``` ...

Subtitle 1

Subtitle 2

... ``` etc. (by the way, temporally overlapping subtitles are permitted as in sample n+1, but that's not really important here - Subtitle 2 could begin at 00:00:18 with no change to the argument) If you mark sample n+1 as redundant then you omit subtitle 2 incorrectly. The way that I envisaged this working is that the implementation would resolve that between 00:00:10 and 00:00:15 sample n _only_ would be active. From 00:00:15 to 00:00:20 sample n+1 _only_ would be active, so all the content that may overlap from sample n into sample n+1's period is irrelevant because that sample has been deactivated/dropped and doesn't generate any visible rendered output. A clever implementation might be able to spot that the Subtitle 1 `

`s are the same and make some optimisations on that basis: that's beyond what the specs say, but certainly permitted if it can be done reliably.

@rbouqueau wrote:

> Not correct. Let's remove the overlapping that is not supported in our EBU-TTD import. MP4Box will create 2 samples:

If your EBU-TT-D import doesn't support it then it has a problem: if you don't support arbitrary and constant (sample/)segment durations then you need a lookup table in the MPD to obtain the the URLs for fetching each sample/segment. This is particularly tricky for live cases. A constant duration model allows the client to construct the URLs - in that case you must expect overlapping content within adjacent samples.

There's no real need to have more than one sample per segment in the case of subtitles - all the samples are going to be in time order anyhow and the segment duration can be quite short. By creating lots of minimally sized samples based on the TTML timings in the content you're most likely to increase the data rate for no benefit.

> Both samples n+1 and n+2 may be part of the same MPEG-DASH segment.

By the same token, they may be part of different segments.

> So IMHO EBU Tech3381 neither recommends nor invalidates the use of 'sample_has_redundancy'.

Agreed. But it isn't necessary to use `sample_has_redundancy`. IMHO it is a special case when adjacent samples do _not_ have some degree of overlap. I don't see the value in setting that attribute to true on most samples since it doesn't help player implementations, which aren't required to take any notice of it anyway, and it's not clear what they should do with the information because it's not specified anywhere.

Sorry for the delay in responding. @rbouqueau I think of the set of times when something changes in the subtitles as being a separate and unrelated list to the set of segment or sample times. Note that a `

` in TTML is not necessarily the same as a subtitle, and multiple `

`s in the same document are permitted with exactly the same, or overlapping, or non-overlapping timings. As @cconcolato pointed out, EBU-TT-D does permit overlapping paragraphs. @cconcolato In your example of one sample for an hour long programme but segments of 1 minute, I wasn't aware that this is possible in DASH. Segments may contain one or more samples, right? Are you suggesting that the samples are duplicated across multiple segments? Or that the URL for the sample in each segment is in fact the same URL? I did not envisage that anyone would want to do that, and I don't see why they would - there's no reason not to create a single 1 hour segment for the subtitle Representation is there? When it comes to setting a redundant flag, I can see how your example would work @cconcolato but only if the sample content is identical. I got the impression before that @rbouqueau was thinking of setting it if some part of the two samples is the same even if some other parts are not. Maybe it helps to work with an example: ##### Input document We start with an EBU-TT-D document that contains: ``` xml

Subtitle 1

Subtitle 2

Subtitle 3

``` Let's say we want, for the sake of example, 5x18s samples. My assumption is that the parts of the document that overlap with each sample period would be extracted, without further editing, which gives: ##### Sample 1 [0-18)s ``` xml

Subtitle 1

``` ##### Sample 2 [18-36)s ``` xml

Subtitle 1

Subtitle 2

``` ##### Sample 3 [36-54)s ``` xml

Subtitle 1

Subtitle 2

``` ##### Sample 4 [54-72)s ``` xml

Subtitle 1

Subtitle 2

Subtitle 3

``` ##### Sample 5 [72-90)s ``` xml

Subtitle 2

Subtitle 3

``` As you can see, samples 2 and 3 do end up being the same, so I guess that 3 could be marked as redundant by @cconcolato's logic above. However each consecutive sample does contain one or more `

`s that's in an adjacent sample too, but in general the samples are not redundant. By the way, the presentation behaviour for those 5 samples should by the specification be indistinguishable from that when the EBU-TT-D processing also modifies the begin and end times to match the sample times, for example sample 2 could become: ``` xml

Subtitle 1

Subtitle 2

``` and sample 3 could become: ``` xml

Subtitle 1

Subtitle 2

``` Presumably if you did that then you could not use the redundant flag for sample 3?

@cconcolato We're in almost complete agreement here. A couple of finer points:

>  if a document is stored in a sample and you have to add a segment boundary in the middle of that sample (for instance because the segment durations are advertised in the MPD with an approximately constant duration), the sample has to be duplicated in the next segment.

This is a special case where a) you don't want to create multiple samples AND b) you don't want to make the segment duration in the subtitle Representation the same as the sample duration. I'm not sure why you'd want this, since the subtitle segment duration does not need to have the same segment duration as e.g. the video. So I don't get the application/use case for this scenario even if I'm sure the statement is correct.

> in practice, the edited version would require terminating the rendering of the previous sample and loading/rendering the new one. That might introduce glitches. The redundant flag is a better option I think.

In the general case it is required to terminate the rendering of the previous sample and beginning rendering the new one. It's unlikely that all samples with any kind of duplication will be able to have the redundant flag set since achieving that would be too difficult for the document author, given that he/she will not know the segment and sample boundaries that will be used at distribution time, and in any case the editorial requirement will be unrelated to those boundaries. 

It's an implementation requirement to avoid glitches on sample boundaries if the presented content in the adjacent boundary frames is the same, regardless of the redundant flag. If I were testing an implementation that glitched e.g. between any adjacent pairs of samples in my example from comment #57 then I would fail that implementation, regardless of the redundant flag or whether the content had been clipped to the sample period or left unchanged.

Going back to the idea of a single sample that is for some reason presented in multiple segments, is there any spec text missing from e.g. [Tech3381](https://tech.ebu.ch/docs/tech/tech3381.pdf), to state that in this scenario the document can remain active across segment boundaries? Just wondering because it isn't a scenario that I think we considered.

What's good about this discussion is that it's clear that there are different starting assumptions, not surprisingly, from different perspectives, e.g. authors, packagers and receivers, and it's important for the whole chain to work and for interoperability to get any kinks in understanding straightened out. We both simultaneously think we're in agreement with each other, and seem to be recognising that there may be challenges from another perspective that we maybe hadn't fully considered.

I'd also add that it's quite hard to discuss all the options in a github thread. I'd be open to a telco or even a face to face meeting to go through the various scenarios and understand what all the parties want to achieve and how they think it would/could work.

In the meantime, I'll try to respond:

> Or rather, you don't want to change the TTML content, yes.

Just to understand this right, by "change the TTML content" you mean "create any new TTML documents at all"? My view so far has been that the process of extracting relevant parts of the initial document, without otherwise modifying them, and using them to synthesise new smaller documents is not a _change_ to the content in itself, but is in fact the process for creating time-restricted samples of TTML.

If you don't want to do that at all, and you have the TTML for the whole programme, then yes, you could just have that one document be the sample, and I don't see any particular problem with the redundant flag approach. It'd be bad for data rates and processing if implementations kept on fetching the same data and reprocessing it though!

> In some live cases, segments have to respect some constraints on their duration, to avoid drift in segment adresses. 

Okay, this is something I need to look into more - I thought this wasn't a problem. Is it a practical issue rather than a theoretical one? What are the attributes of the live cases that make them susceptible to this?

> In multiplexed representations, you want to keep the subtitle data aligned with the media data.

This could mean a couple of things, so can I unpack what you mean? By "multiplexed representations" are you talking about Representations containing multiple Sub-Representations, one of which contains the subtitle media content component? Or do you mean Representations that contain MPEG-2 transport stream Media Segments that contain multiplexed content? I don't think anyone has defined the carriage of TTML in MPEG-2 TS yet, so it'd be good if we can rule that out for the time being.

Assuming you mean the first one, yes, I can see that the segment boundaries are the same for all the Sub-Representations present. 

So I think I get that use case now, thanks.

> I'm thinking the segmenter would create those redundant samples, as it's easier than to edit the TTML content.

It's actually pretty easy (computationally, and in code) to pull out the TTML content that overlaps any given defined time period from a single document covering a longer period. I've seen an XSLT that can do it, for example. It's even simpler in EBU-TT-D than generic TTML because some of the time calculation complexities are reduced. MP4Box seems to have code to do this already.

But yes, doing _no_ processing is always easier than doing _some_ processing!

Since _some_ packagers will create temporal samples from the TTML, and it's allowed in the specs, it follows that _all_ receiver implementations need to be able to handle it. I think that's the macro point here. I'm very happy with any assistance that can be provided in packaging and any optimisations in implementations to help provide the right user experience.

So ...

> I'm not sure I follow here. The document author may not have the information about the segment duration, but the segmenter has that information.

We maybe were coming from two different starting points: I thought we were talking about a model where TTML samples matching the segment period were being extracted from the source TTML; I now see that you weren't saying that. In the model I had in mind, my point was simply that there is no and can be no fixed relationship between the begin and end times in the original (pre-sampling) TTML and the segment times, meaning that some TTML content will end up being reproduced in adjacent samples some of the time.

It feels as though we've almost reached the end of this discussion, with some useful notes for future reference. I agree with the points about where the processing should happen, and the proposed model is fine for me. 

Attempting to summarise:
- It is the role of the Encoder to take TTML input documents and create samples of TTML suitable for packaging.
- It is the role of the Packager to create DASHed output including or referencing those encoded samples.
- Encoders may create multiple samples of TTML (e.g. EBU-TT-D) that have defined sample periods in ISOBMFF but have timed (TTML) content that extends outside those periods;
- Encoders do not have to do this and could create a single long sample for the duration of the media content;
- Packagers may create multiple DASH segments that reference the same TTML sample;
- Packagers may label the redundant samples as 'redundant = true';
- Adjacent TTML samples may contain some duplicated content, e.g. a timed content element that extends across the sample boundary may be in both the samples.
- Packagers must not label non-identical samples as redundant even if they partially overlap;
- If the desired DASHed output has segments with distinct samples, e.g. for live content, then the encoder needs to be aware of the desired segment boundaries and create the TTML samples to match (or an integral number of samples that matches the segment duration
- Decoders may take advantage of the redundant flag to extend the active duration of a sample
- Decoders must ensure that zero or one TTML sample in a media component (i.e with the same `@id`) is active at any given moment on the media timeline. It is an error to permit two or more samples to be active simultaneously even if their content overlaps in time.
- On sample and segment boundaries, any presented content that is the same before and after the boundary point the implementation must not have a visible glitch in presentation.

Before we consider closing this, I just want to check if there are any remaining unresolved questions.

In particular:
- are the models for DASHing and playback clear enough?
- are there any remaining points of debate?
- are there scenarios that are under-specified by 14496-30, 23009 and/or Tech3381?

review_comments.body:
These two `tt:p` elements are not in the TTML namespace; since this is an EBU-TT-D example file it is invalid for two reasons:

1. The EBU-TT-D spec does not allow content from other namespaces except in metadata
2. The cardinality of the `p` element as a child of `div` is `1..*`; this `div` has zero child TTML `p` elements (i.e. `p` elements in the correct namespace) so it is not conformant. The `p` elements in the non-TTML namespace do not count here.

issue_comments.body:
Mhmm, i still get the bug in Chromium when i use your command. Another:
`$ MP4Box -inter 500 file_001.mp4`
afterwards gets around it.

So, what could be the difference? What is the second command doing to the file?

Is there a way to dump the chunk information or something, so one could see the difference?

Chromium fires many tiny range requests when one jumps into the second half of the video. I haven't filed a bug report yet, as i wanted to understand first what's wrong with the video file.

Here are step-by-step instructions to reproduce with a public video:

get video https://durian.blender.org/download/
`$ wget 'http://mirrorblender.top-ix.org/movies/sintel-1280-surround.mp4'`

split file:
`$ MP4Box -splits 150000 -inter 500 sintel-1280-surround.mp4`

open first part sintel-1280-surround_001.mp4 here in Chromium:
https://tetzank.github.io/videojs-shortcuts/demo_playlist.html

open Console with Ctrl+Shift+j and switch to the Network tab

press play and then jump near the end of the video

In the network tab you'll see many tiny requests. Over the internet this adds too much overhead and delay, so the video can't be played back smoothly.

It can be fixed with:
`$ MP4Box -inter 500 sintel-1280-surround_001.mp4`

This commit unfortunately breaks installation from source on MacOS X - see issue https://github.com/gpac/gpac/issues/317 for details.
There's a non-breaking space in these media-object.c lines again breaking builds.
This actually breaks 32-bit builds since `/mingw64` still exists.

I think a proper test should check what's the target of $CC before assuming absolute paths or just force people to pass `--target-os`. Would be preferable, imho.
Either way, reverting this commit does fix compilation with media-autobuild_suite for now, so it's not that serious.

No, just those two. At least within the suite Msys2 GCC is never installed. Even if it were, `/mingw{32,64}/bin` always come before `/usr/bin` in $PATH. Msys2 GCC is only supposed to be used when compiling to Msys2, since they will depend on Msys2 DLLs, like cygwin.
MSYS compilers are not supposed to be used for anything other than MSYS tools.

I do not think so; the error message has to to with the Android SDK. It cannot find it, no matter whether you set its path as an argument to the build script, or you have set the ANDROID_HOME variable

review_comments.body: I am sure that only one line from my pull request should be used and it is not the one you point to.

Can you point me to the location in the CENC spec where the it should be blocksize+1 for the current counter after a subsample encrypt (with remaining counter)?  I didn't see anything that would suggest we needed to +1 byte but we may have missed something.

Our CENC decryption routines don't skip any bytes.  E.g. if 8 bytes of counter is left, we consume the 8 bytes of the counter.
